item.title: cj - A Command Line Utility for Common Dev Tasks I Do
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded:
CJ is a command line utility I built to make it quicker for me to run common commands. You can download it as an NPM module: cj-cmd. The utlity acts as a wrapper around many existing libraries, so it is normally the only global plugin I would ever install on a development machine. When installed globally you can then use it by running e.g: cj install react-js Here's a run down of the commands so far:
  • install - Wrapper around Yeoman so that I can install any Yeoman templates that are dependencies of the cj module. The main benefit of this is that you do not have to install each generator/template manually first, as they are all bundled within this utility.
  • run - A wrapper around global-commands, another one of my npm modules that lets you run common commands from any directory, so you don't need to "cd" to some potential long and hard to remember directory first
  • update - A command that will update all the node packages in the file you run it from. This will always update to the latest version rather than respecting the specified semver number.
  • update --self - Is an option that can be passed to update the cj-cmd module.
At some point I'm looking to add system checks into this plugin so that it will download/install or tell you what your system needs in order to run various projects. This will help me maintain a consistent development environment and stop forgetting which Atom plugins I have installed at work but not on my home machine yet. This type of utility is super handy and can be adapted for organisations to use, in order to let your developers all share the same template generators, linting guides etc.
item.excerpt:encoded: CJ is a command line utility I built to make it quicker for me to run common commands. You can download it as an NPM module: cj-cmd. The utlity acts as a wrapper around many existing libraries, so it is normally the only global plugin I would ever install on a development machine.

item.title: flow-check - An NPM Package for Automatically Adding Flow Type Support to Files
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded: This is a small npm package that adds the Flow type comment header to all your projects Javascript files and then runs flow. Useful when using Flow from the start of a project, as Flow requires you to have the comment in each file you want to check. You can check out the repo here on GitHub.

item.title: Daily Photo
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded: Since March 2017 I have been taking and posting a photo every day. A bit of it is for documenting the places and things I'm seeing, improving my photography eye and also training the mind to see beauty in anything. Which helps towards developing a positive mindset. Also... I really enjoy writing ridiculous comments with each photo I post. Check them out on my Instagram.

item.title: Daily Doodle - Doing a Drawing Every Day
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded: From March 2017 I have been doing a sketch every day. I'ts mixture of observational drawings and making up weird and wonderful stuff. Most of the drawings are done using the Noteshelf Application on my iPad Pro, and using the Apple Pencil for fine control. A setup I'd highly recommend. Noteshelf is great for taking notes as you can sync each notebook directly with Evernote and Dropbox for backup. Apps like Photoshop Sketch are better for more detailed drawings and using layers, but I enjoy Noteshelf for doing little doodles and keeping them all in one place. Check out all my daily drawings on my Pinterest board or follow me on Instagram.

item.title: Wordpress React Template - A Yeoman Template for Headless WordPress, Node and React
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded:
My current project looks at building a Yeoman template for setting up a React website powered by Wordpress. Here's my current plan:
  • Use Docker for every service
  • Run Wordpress as a headless CMS
  • Have a node server to serve the react content
  • Use Jenkins for continuous integration and deployment
  • Integrate content and database backups
  • Be flexible enough for use on many different types of projects with a similar setup
You can check out the progress on the repo here on GitHub.
item.excerpt:encoded: My current project looks at building a Yeoman template for setting up a React website powered by Wordpress

item.title: Jenkins - Continuous Deployment and Integration
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded: For a lot of my projects recently the deployment process has been a bitch. And especially when I come back to a project after a few months, I would have forgotten a lot of the nuances in the deployment process for that specific project. Firstly I need better documentation but also, I'm lazy, so lets automate this. Incomes Jenkins to the rescue. Jenkins is an automation server which makes it easy to deploy, test and automate any other task with your project. As the only thing Jenkins can't do is set up itself, unless you have another Jenkins server already setup, but let's assume this is your first one. So I have created a handy repo with some scripts and documentation for getting Jenkins setup with the packages I use and some little quirks to help everything run smoother. You can check out the repo here on GitHub.
item.excerpt:encoded: For a lot of my projects recently the deployment process has been a bitch. And especially when I come back to a project after a few months, I would have forgotten a lot of the nuances in the deployment process for that specific project. Firstly I need better documentation but also, I'm lazy, so lets automate this. Incomes Jenkins to the rescue.

item.title: Mantras - A Collection of Learnings
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded:
I have a list of mantra and sayings that I've collected from various books, podcasts and talks. These are thing's that either inspire me or are principles I want to try and live by. Many of them contradict each other as well, so they are more thought provoking, than a definitive list of things I stand by. I also setup a cheeky Google Script that automatically emails a random one to me everyday, as a way to remind me of some of the thing's I've though about over the years.
  • Above and beyond
  • Be mindful at everything you do
  • Breathe better
  • Fully embrace your senses
  • Do, Record, Relive
  • Automate as much as possible
  • Be effective not just efficient
  • Destuffocate
  • What are the most absurb ways to solve your problems?
  • Does this add to my short or long term happiness?
  • Make mistakes of ambition, not mistakes of sloth
  • You don't have to finish everything you start
  • Are you being productive or just active?
  • Find the 20% of work that counts for 80%
  • What you do is more important than how you do it
  • Excitement is the phsyical sympton of happiness
  • Leverage strengths rather than fix weaknesses
  • Unreasonable and unrealistic goals are easier to achieve than normal ones.
  • What gets measured, gets managed
  • Act with the intention of being remarkable
  • Measurement = motivation
  • Beginners mind, treat everything as being new
  • Act with the curiosity of a child
  • Jump and justify
  • Yes and
  • Find the most obvious ways to solve a problem
  • Don't overcomplicate, everything can be easy and simple
  • The best ideas are often psychotic, obscene and unoriginal
  • Don't be afraid to show your flaws
  • Don't postpone decision making
  • Are you doing something important?
  • Constantly look for things to remove
  • Clear your mind
  • Think inside the box
  • Striving for originality makes your work mediocre
  • Remove as much mental load as you can
  • Get rid of all notifications
  • If something takes less than 2 mins to do, do it!
  • Focus on one thing at a time
  • Adjust your environment to promote better motivation
  • Focus!
  • Ask friends and randomers opinions on the work you are doing right now
  • Striving for perfection will prevent you from taking flight
  • Stress derives from not being able to choose one idea over another

item.title: Meditation - Mindfulness practice for a happier life
item.dc:creator: charlie
item.content:encoded:
I have been meditating on and off for the last few years. But in the last 70 days I have been doing 5-10 minutes every day to find out what the prolonged benefits of daily meditation are. Here's what I've found:
  • I can prioritise and organise much better
    • This was one of my key stress factors, always wanting to do too much and getting overwhelmed with all the tasks I felt needed to get done. Meditation has helped me to realise that a task may not actually be important and has helped me to define a clear priority of tasks. Greatly reducing my stress.
  • I can stay focused for longer, so I'm more efficient
  • My breathing is much better
  • My mind is calmer, and doesn't race around as much
    • Slower more deliberate though
  • I am more forgiving, and more likely to see the good in people
  • I am less worried about the future, and am focusing more on the present
  • I am more honest with myself about my own thoughts, opinions and emotions
My daily practice looks like:
  • Grabbing one of the giant pillows Viki made from our honeymoon
  • Sitting cross legged
  • Opening the Calm app and picking one of the 5, 10 or 15 minute sessions. My favourites are:
    • Calm Light
      • Less talk
    • Timed Meditation
      • No talk
    • Choices
      • Guided talk session around noticing distractions
    • Body Scan
      • Guided talk session focusing on awareness of your entire body
item.excerpt:encoded: I have been meditating on and off for the last few years. But in the last 70 days I have been doing 5-10 minutes every day to find out what the prolonged benefits of daily meditation are.
